abstract.p: Long Island podiatrist Lance Greiff offers precautions when walking barefoot; photo (M)

block.p: WALKING barefoot has advantages. It strengthens the foot's small muscles and enhances sensory stimulation.

But except for toddlers, who should not wear shoes until they are walking, going barefoot is not always a great idea, cautions Dr. Lance Greiff, a podiatrist with practices in Great Neck and Riverdale.

But except for toddlers, who should not wear shoes until they are walking, going barefoot is not always a great idea, cautions Dr. Lance Greiff, a podiatrist with practices in Great Neck and Riverdale.

''I probably say 40 times a day, 'Don't walk barefoot,' '' Dr. Greiff said. ''There's not much good about walking barefoot. Walking or exercising on uneven terrain such as the beach can put added strain on certain tendons and muscles.''
Even walking barefoot in your own backyard can cause athlete's foot and viral plantar warts.
And walking barefoot on hot sand can cause burns on the soles of the feet and lead to leg, knee or back pain.
''We rarely recommend walking barefoot because there are more disadvantages than advantages,'' Dr. Greiff said.
He also suggested these precautions when walking barefoot:
* Do not walk or exercise through pain.
* Avoid prolonged exposure to heat or cold.
* Walk on clean surfaces that offer shock absorption.
He also urges seeking professional help if problems develop.
